Review: Bargain basement film was twistier than it had the right to be! Almost everyone is ice cold, especially June Vincent, who is rocking some very elegant streaks in her hair.

Conventional but filled with strong performances and every emotional beat still hit. And everyone looked good doing it! Sorry to Aidan Quinn. Tweaking my rating upon considering some of the film’s artistic liberties.
Finnish Adam Driver and Glenn Close are two losers in love in this early Kaurismäki, which bears many striking similarities to Fallen Leaves while being not half as funny.
Stunning! Tense! Ahead of its time! Robot Maria had moves.

Finnish Michelle Williams save me! Apt musical cues, deadpan humor, and tender gestures anchor this ode to imperfect love set against the backdrop of the cinema. In one standout scene, a connection is both made and missed in front of a poster for Brief Encounter. In another, I found my new favorite Finnish pop song. Still others turn mundane activities like drinking and working into a ballet. While the treatment of alcoholism could be more nuanced and the war dispatches on the radio occasIonally feel heavy-handed, this film was tight and beautiful and left me with a lot of hope.

I’ve always been distracted watching this—namely, cooking Thanksgiving dinner—and it’s one of my dad’s childhood favorites, so I got him the dvd for Christmas and promised we’d watch it together. When I think of classic Christmas movies, I often think of this in the same breath as It’s A Wonderful Life. While that movie tugs at the emotional, this one’s more focused on the cerebral: the business case for Santa Claus, the commodification of mental health, the stories we tell…

Did I enjoy watching this? Not always. Is it brilliant? Yeah. Robert Ryan is an absolute sicko as always and Ida Lupino is just incredible as the vulnerable yet strong young war widow he holds hostage. Really creative shots—especially one with Ryan’s reflection in Christmas ornaments—and careful nuances level up this fairly straightforward, tense film that keeps you on the edge of your seat for all 77 minutes.

Movie: I Wouldn't Be in Your Shoes
Review: SHOES! SHOES! SHOES! imagine being so down bad as the cop in this movie. I wish it had stuck to Woolrich’s original story, which would have been more chilling and less hokey. I did like the moments of community among the prisoners. Don Castle is Walmart Cary Grant?
Paul Giamatti at the ice rink…that look of loneliness, watching Tully’s joy…says it all. Occasionally heavy-handed but really hopeful and nice.
Rewatch with my mom for her birthday. Ending kinda drags for me, but I’m still weeping at America Ferrera’s monologue. Sure, it’s not groundbreaking stuff, but it needs to be said.
The version on Max is a lot higher quality than the dvd we have, really allowing the subtle facial reactions to shine. Unsung heroes: Christmas tree salesman, glasses kid.
